body_html:
Hey! I had this problem while compiling on a Raspberry Pi. The sum of the answer is: your machine is running out of memory. In my case, adding a usb drive and partitioning it as swap worked fine. Here are the steps I took to add swap, which I got from the ask Ubuntu forums.

Afterward, you'll probably want to safely remove the swap disk, so you could just follow these instructions

Just for further discussion- I'm not certain, but I believe the "No such file or directory" bug has to do with the Bazel build process creating some form of temporary file. That bug only occurs when you run the gcc command on it's own. I encountered the same issue here. eigen-eigen-c5e90d9e764e only exists when running through the entire Bazel process.

Afterward, you'll probably want to safely remove the swap disk, so you could just follow these instructions

body:
Hey! I had this problem while compiling on a Raspberry Pi. The sum of the answer is: your machine is running out of memory. In my case, adding a usb drive and partitioning it as swap worked fine. [Here](https://github.com/samjabrahams/tensorflow-on-raspberry-pi/blob/master/GUIDE.md#4-install-a-memory-drive-as-swap-for-compiling) are the steps I took to add swap, which I got from the [ask Ubuntu forums](http://askubuntu.com/questions/173676/how-to-make-a-usb-stick-swap-disk).

Afterward, you'll probably want to safely remove the swap disk, so you could just follow [these instructions](http://askubuntu.com/questions/616437/is-it-safe-to-delete-a-swap-partition-on-a-usb-install)

---

Just for further discussion- I'm not certain, but I believe the "No such file or directory" bug has to do with the Bazel build process creating some form of temporary file. That bug only occurs when you run the `gcc` command on it's own. I encountered the same issue [here](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/445#issuecomment-195548409). `eigen-eigen-c5e90d9e764e` only exists when running through the entire Bazel process.
